Michael Yudelson yudelson@andrew.cmu.edu
info.abstract: The Bayesian Knowledge Tracing (BKT) performs inference from time-series data of student attempts to apply their knowledge.
info.description: BKT is a user modeling approach widely use in the area of Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITS). In ITS, it is customary to tag problems and problem steps students are solving with knowledge quanta often called skills. When a student is attempting to solve a problem or a problem step, they are said to practice a skill. A student model in a general sense performs deductions on whether the skill(s) is (are) mastered given a sequence of correct and incorrect attempts to solve a problems/problem steps that are tagged with it. The goal of BKT is to infer whether the student has mastered a skill or not from a pattern of successful or unsuccessful attempts to apply it. BKT uses a formalism of a Hidden Markov Model to estimate student's skill mastery. In BKT, there are two types of nodes: binary state nodes capture skill mastery (one per skill) that assume values of mastered or not mastered and binary observation nodes (one per skill) that assume values of correct or incorrect.
info.outputs:
Student-Step – model predictions.
Model values – fit statistics.
Parameters – BKT parameter values.
info.options:
Model – the column containing the Knowledge Component Model (KCM) data.
Solver – the algorithm used to fit the BKT model.
Max Iterations – the maximum number of iterations the solver would run to fit the BKT model.
Initial Parameters – starting values of BKT parameters.
Lower Boundaries – lower boundaries for the BKT parameters (cannot be lower than 0).
Upper Boundaries – upper boundaries for the BKT parameters (cannot be higher than 1).
Cross-validation Folds – the parameter for K-folds cross-validation.
